channel.title: NASA ScienceCasts
channel.description: NASA Science news is too exciting for plain text. Educational "ScienceCast" videos are fun, lively, entertaining--and anything but plain. Join us for a new episode every week as we look into the science behind discoveries on Earth, the Solar System, and beyond...
channel.itunes:subtitle: NASA Science news is too exciting for plain text. Educational "ScienceCast" videos are fun, lively, entertaining--anything but plain. Join us for a new episode weekly as we look into the science behind discoveries on Earth, the Solar System, and beyond...
channel.itunes:summary: NASA Science news is too exciting for plain text. Educational "ScienceCast" videos are fun, lively, entertaining--anything but plain. Join us for a new episode weekly as we look into the science behind discoveries on Earth, the Solar System, and beyond...
channel.itunes:author: NASA Science

item.title: ScienceCast 77: Weird Planets
item.itunes:author: NASA Science
item.itunes:subtitle: Once, astronomers thought planets couldn't form around binary stars. Now Kepler has found a whole system of planers orbiting a double star. This finding shows that planetary systems are weirder and more abundant than previously thought.
item.itunes:summary: Once, astronomers thought planets couldn't form around binary stars. Now Kepler has found a whole system of planers orbiting a double star. This finding shows that planetary systems are weirder and more abundant than previously thought.
item.itunes:keywords: Kepler, exoplanets, astrobiology, double stars, alien life
item.author: michael.brody-1@nasa.gov (NASA Science)

item.title: ScienceCast 76: The Radiation Belt Storm Probes
item.itunes:author: NASA Science
item.itunes:subtitle: This morning NASA launched two heavily-shielded spacecraft directly into the Van Allen Belts. The Radiation Belt Storm Probes are on a two-year mission to study the Van Allen Belts and to unravel the mystery of their unpredictability.
item.itunes:summary: This morning NASA launched two heavily-shielded spacecraft directly into the Van Allen Belts. The Radiation Belt Storm Probes are on a two-year mission to study the Van Allen Belts and to unravel the mystery of their unpredictability.
item.itunes:keywords: NASA, NASA Science, Science, National Aeronautics and Space Administration, ScienceCasts, SMD, Science Mission Directorate, Science@NASA News, Blue Moon, full Moon, volcano, forest fires, Elvis
item.author: michael.brody-1@nasa.gov (NASA Science)

item.title: ScienceCast 75: Watch Out For The Blue Moon
item.itunes:author: NASA Science
item.itunes:subtitle: The second full Moon of August--a "Blue Moon"--is just around the corner. It will probably look just like any other full Moon but, on rare occasions, the Moon really does turn blue. Could it happen this month?
item.itunes:summary: The second full Moon of August--a "Blue Moon"--is just around the corner. It will probably look just like any other full Moon but, on rare occasions, the Moon really does turn blue. Could it happen this month?
item.itunes:keywords: NASA, NASA Science, Science, National Aeronautics and Space Administration, ScienceCasts, SMD, Science Mission Directorate, Science@NASA News, radiation, Van Allen Belts, heliophysics, space weather, solar flares, sunspots, geomagnetic storms
item.author: michael.brody-1@nasa.gov (NASA Science)

item.title: ScienceCast 74: Where Will Curiosity Go First?
item.itunes:author: NASA Science
item.itunes:subtitle: Curiosity is safe on Mars and ready to roll. In this video from Science@NASA, project scientist John Grotzinger discusses where the rover might go first.
item.itunes:summary: Curiosity is safe on Mars and ready to roll. In this video from Science@NASA, project scientist John Grotzinger discusses where the rover might go first.
item.itunes:keywords: NASA, NASA Science, Science, National Aeronautics and Space Administration, ScienceCasts, SMD, Science Mission Directorate, Science@NASA News, Mars, rover, Curiosity, Mt. Sharp, Gale Crater
item.author: michael.brody-1@nasa.gov (NASA Science)

item.title: ScienceCast 73: 2012 Perseid Meteor Shower
item.itunes:author: NASA Science
item.itunes:subtitle: The Perseid meteor shower is underway. There's more to see than meteors, however, when the shower peaks on August 11th through 13th. The brightest planets in the solar system are lining up in the middle of the display.
item.itunes:summary: The Perseid meteor shower is underway. There's more to see than meteors, however, when the shower peaks on August 11th through 13th. The brightest planets in the solar system are lining up in the middle of the display.
item.itunes:keywords: NASA, NASA Science, Science, National Aeronautics and Space Administration, ScienceCasts, SMD, Science Mission Directorate, Science@NASA News, meteors, Perseids, Venus, Jupiter, planetary alignment, comet, Swift-Tuttle
item.author: michael.brody-1@nasa.gov (NASA Science)

item.title: ScienceCast 72: Meteor Smoke Makes Strange Clouds
item.itunes:author: NASA Science
item.itunes:subtitle: A key ingredient of Earth's strangest clouds does not come from Earth. New data from NASA's AIM spacecraft proves that "meteor smoke" is essential to the formation of noctilucent clouds.
item.itunes:summary: A key ingredient of Earth's strangest clouds does not come from Earth. New data from NASA's AIM spacecraft proves that "meteor smoke" is essential to the formation of noctilucent clouds.
item.itunes:keywords: NASA, NASA Science, Science, National Aeronautics and Space Administration, ScienceCasts, SMD, Science Mission Directorate, Science@NASA News, climate change, noctilucent clouds, methane, meteor, NLC
item.author: michael.brody-1@nasa.gov (NASA Science)

item.title: ScienceCast 71: Mars Landing Sky Show
item.itunes:author: NASA Science
item.itunes:subtitle: On the same night Curiosity lands on Mars, a "Martian Triangle" will appear in sunset skies of Earth.
item.itunes:summary: On the same night Curiosity lands on Mars, a "Martian Triangle" will appear in sunset skies of Earth.
item.itunes:keywords: NASA, NASA Science, Science, National Aeronautics and Space Administration, ScienceCasts, SMD, Science Mission Directorate, Science@NASA News, Mars, Red Planet, Curiosity, Saturn, Spica, rover
item.author: michael.brody-1@nasa.gov (NASA Science)

item.title: ScienceCast 70: A Taste of Solar Maximum
item.itunes:author: NASA Science
item.itunes:subtitle: This month sky watchers got a taste of things to come when a powerful flare sparked Northern Lights over the United States.
item.itunes:summary: This month sky watchers got a taste of things to come when a powerful flare sparked Northern Lights over the United States.

item.title: ScienceCast 69: The First Extraterrestrial Marathon
item.itunes:author: NASA Science
item.itunes:subtitle: Mars rover Opportunity is still running 8 years after landing. The tireless robot is about to complete a full marathon!
item.itunes:summary: Mars rover Opportunity is still running 8 years after landing. The tireless robot is about to complete a full marathon!

item.title: ScienceCast 68: A Good Reason to Wake Up at Dawn
item.itunes:author: NASA Science
item.itunes:subtitle: The brightest planets in the solar system are converging for a beautiful sunrise sky show in early July.
item.itunes:summary: The brightest planets in the solar system are converging for a beautiful sunrise sky show in early July.

item.title: ScienceCast 67: Hidden Magnetic Portals Around Earth
item.itunes:author: NASA Science
item.itunes:subtitle: A NASA-sponsored researcher at the University of Iowa has developed a way for spacecraft to hunt down hidden magnetic portals in the vicinity of Earth.
item.itunes:summary: A NASA-sponsored researcher at the University of Iowa has developed a way for spacecraft to hunt down hidden magnetic portals in the vicinity of Earth.

item.title: ScienceCast 66: Voyager 1 at the Final Frontier
item.itunes:author: NASA Science
item.itunes:subtitle: At the edge of the solar system, Voyager 1 is reporting a sharp increase in cosmic rays that could herald the spacecraft's long-awaited entry into interstellar space.
item.itunes:summary: At the edge of the solar system, Voyager 1 is reporting a sharp increase in cosmic rays that could herald the spacecraft's long-awaited entry into interstellar space.

item.title: ScienceCast 65: Why Won't the Supernova Explode?
item.itunes:author: NASA Science
item.itunes:subtitle: A question has been troubling astronomers: Why won't the supernova explode? NASA has launched a new observatory named "NuSTAR" to seek out the missing physics of exploding stars.
item.itunes:summary: A question has been troubling astronomers: Why won't the supernova explode? NASA has launched a new observatory named "NuSTAR" to seek out the missing physics of exploding stars.
item.itunes:keywords: NASA, NASA Science, Science, National Aeronautics and Space Administration, ScienceCasts, SMD, Science Mission Directorate, Science@NASA News, NuSTAR, black holes, supernova, x-ray astronomy, space telescope
item.author: michael.brody-1@nasa.gov (NASA Science)

item.title: ScienceCast 64: Andromeda vs. the Milky Way: Astronomers Predict a Titanic Collision
item.itunes:author: NASA Science
item.itunes:subtitle: Astronomers no longer have any doubt: Our Milky Way Galaxy will have a head-on collision with Andromeda. Fortunately, they say, Earth will survive when the two great star systems meet 4 billions years from now.
item.itunes:summary: Astronomers no longer have any doubt: Our Milky Way Galaxy will have a head-on collision with Andromeda. Fortunately, they say, Earth will survive when the two great star systems meet 4 billions years from now.

item.title: ScienceCast 63: ISS Transit of Venus
item.itunes:author: NASA Science
item.itunes:subtitle: On Monday, June 4th, the Moon will pass through the shadow of Earth, producing a partial lunar eclipse visible across the Pacific from China to the United States.
item.itunes:summary: On Monday, June 4th, the Moon will pass through the shadow of Earth, producing a partial lunar eclipse visible across the Pacific from China to the United States.

item.itunes:author: NASA Science
item.itunes:subtitle: On Monday, June 4th, the Moon will pass through the shadow of Earth, producing a partial lunar eclipse visible across the Pacific from China to the United States.

item.title: ScienceCast 61: The 2012 Transit of Venus
item.itunes:author: NASA Science
item.itunes:subtitle: It won't happen again until December 2117. On June 5th, 2012, Venus will transit the face of the sun in an event of both historical and observational importance.
item.itunes:summary: It won't happen again until December 2117. On June 5th, 2012, Venus will transit the face of the sun in an event of both historical and observational importance.

item.author: michael.brody-1@nasa.gov (NASA Science)

item.title: ScienceCast 60: Don't Judge a Moon by its Cover
item.itunes:author: NASA Science
item.itunes:subtitle: Superficially, Saturn's moon Phoebe doesn't look much like a planet, but on the inside, the little gray moon has a lot in common with worlds like Earth.
item.itunes:summary: Superficially, Saturn's moon Phoebe doesn't look much like a planet, but on the inside, the little gray moon has a lot in common with worlds like Earth.

item.title: ScienceCast 59: A Star Turns Inside Out
item.itunes:author: NASA Science
item.itunes:subtitle: NASA's Chandra X-ray Observatory has mapped the debris of a supernova and discovered that the explosion may have turned the original star inside out.
item.itunes:summary: NASA's Chandra X-ray Observatory has mapped the debris of a supernova and discovered that the explosion may have turned the original star inside out.
item.itunes:keywords: NASA, NASA Science, Science, National Aeronautics and Space Administration, ScienceCasts, SMD, Science Mission Directorate, Science@NASA News, supernova, Chandra, X-ray astronomy, origins of life, Carl Sagan

item.title: ScienceCast 58: Amateur Scientists Discover Galactic Bubbles
item.itunes:author: NASA Science
item.itunes:subtitle: Amateur scientists have made a effervescent discovery: The Milky Way Galaxy is bubbling like a glass of champagne.
item.itunes:summary: Amateur scientists have made a effervescent discovery: The Milky Way Galaxy is bubbling like a glass of champagne.

item.title: ScienceCast 57: Here Comes Solar Maximum
item.itunes:author: NASA Science
item.itunes:subtitle: Solar storms and Northern Lights are in the offing as the sun approaches Solar Max, expected in mid-to-late 2013. Recently, Earth's defenses were tested by a volley of strong eruptions.
item.itunes:summary: Solar storms and Northern Lights are in the offing as the sun approaches Solar Max, expected in mid-to-late 2013. Recently, Earth's defenses were tested by a volley of strong eruptions.

item.title: ScienceCast 56: April is the Cruelest Month
item.itunes:author: NASA Science
item.itunes:subtitle: One year after the historic tornado outbreak of April 27-28, 2011, researchers say they've learned a few things about deadly twisters. This week's ScienceCast presents some of the scientific findings that emerged from the swath of destruction.
item.itunes:summary: One year after the historic tornado outbreak of April 27-28, 2011, researchers say they've learned a few things about deadly twisters. This week's ScienceCast presents some of the scientific findings that emerged from the swath of destruction.
item.itunes:keywords: NASA, NASA Science, Science, National Aeronautics and Space Administration, ScienceCasts, SMD, Science Mission Directorate, Science@NASA News, tornadoes, super cell thunderstorms, severe weather
item.author: michael.brody-1@nasa.gov (NASA Science)

item.title: ScienceCast 55: A Wonderful Night in April
item.itunes:author: NASA Science
item.itunes:subtitle: If you have to chose just one night in April to go out and look at the stars, NASA scientists say it should be April 21st. This week's ScienceCast explains what makes that one night so special.
item.itunes:summary: If you have to chose just one night in April to go out and look at the stars, NASA scientists say it should be April 21st. This week's ScienceCast explains what makes that one night so special.

item.title: ScienceCast 54: Getting to Know the Goldilocks Planet
item.itunes:author: NASA Science
item.itunes:subtitle: NASA's Kepler spacecraft is discovering a veritable avalanche of alien worlds. It seems to be just a matter of time before Kepler finds what astronomers are really looking for: an Earth-like planet orbiting its star in the "Goldilocks zone".
item.itunes:summary: NASA's Kepler spacecraft is discovering a veritable avalanche of alien worlds. It seems to be just a matter of time before Kepler finds what astronomers are really looking for: an Earth-like planet orbiting its star in the "Goldilocks zone".

item.author: michael.brody-1@nasa.gov (NASA Science)

item.title: ScienceCast 53: The Surprising Power of a Solar Storm
item.itunes:author: NASA Science
item.itunes:subtitle: A flurry of solar activity in early March dumped enough heat in Earth's upper atmosphere to power every residence in New York City for two years. The heat has since dissipated, but there's more to come as the solar cycle intensifies.
item.itunes:summary: A flurry of solar activity in early March dumped enough heat in Earth's upper atmosphere to power every residence in New York City for two years. The heat has since dissipated, but there's more to come as the solar cycle intensifies.
item.itunes:keywords: NASA, NASA Science, Science, National Aeronautics and Space Administration, ScienceCasts, SMD, Science Mission Directorate, Science@NASA News, space weather, solar flares, coronal mass ejections, thermosphere, SABER, TIMED, New York
item.author: michael.brody-1@nasa.gov (NASA Science)

item.title: ScienceCast 52: Mysterious Objects at the Edge of the Electromagnetic Spectrum
item.itunes:author: NASA Science
item.itunes:subtitle: NASA's Fermi Gamma-Ray Telescope is finding hundreds of new objects at the very edge of the electromagnetic spectrum.Many of them have one thing in common: Astronomers have no idea what they are.
item.itunes:summary: NASA's Fermi Gamma-Ray Telescope is finding hundreds of new objects at the very edge of the electromagnetic spectrum.Many of them have one thing in common: Astronomers have no idea what they are.

item.title: ScienceCast 51: The Super Moon of May 2012
item.itunes:author: NASA Science
item.itunes:subtitle: Another "super-Moon" is in the offing. The perigee full Moon in May will be as much as 14% bigger and 30% brighter than other full moons of 2012.
item.itunes:summary: Another "super-Moon" is in the offing. The perigee full Moon in May will be as much as 14% bigger and 30% brighter than other full moons of 2012.

item.itunes:subtitle: Lately, the International Space Station has been flying through geomagnetic storms, giving astronauts an close-up view of the aurora borealis just outside their windows.

item.itunes:author: NASA Science
item.itunes:subtitle: A "ring of fire" solar eclipse is coming to the USA this spring. It's the first annular eclipse visible from the contiguous United States in almost 18 years.

item.itunes:author: NASA Science

item.itunes:subtitle: NASA's Dawn probe has found some surprising things on the giant asteroid Vesta--things that have prompted one researcher to declare Vesta "the smallest terrestrial planet."

item.title: ScienceCast 38: The Great Lakes of Europa
item.itunes:author: NASA Science
item.itunes:subtitle: Scientists studying data from NASA's Galileo probe have discovered what appears to be a body of liquid water the volume of the North American Great Lakes locked inside the icy shell of Jupiter's moon Europa.
item.itunes:summary: Scientists studying data from NASA's Galileo probe have discovered what appears to be a body of liquid water the volume of the North American Great Lakes locked inside the icy shell of Jupiter's moon Europa.

item.title: ScienceCast 37: Terrifying Auroras
item.itunes:author: NASA Science
item.itunes:subtitle: A distant world is being hit by solar storms so ferocious, the entire planet is probably enveloped in auroras. Researchers speculate that the display is probably as beautiful as it is terrifying.
item.itunes:summary: A distant world is being hit by solar storms so ferocious, the entire planet is probably enveloped in auroras. Researchers speculate that the display is probably as beautiful as it is terrifying.

item.title: ScienceCast 36: Mystery of the Lunar Ionosphere
item.itunes:author: NASA Science
item.itunes:subtitle: How can a world without air have an ionosphere? Somehow the Moon has done it. Lunar researchers have been struggling with this mystery for years, and they may have finally found a solution.
item.itunes:summary: How can a world without air have an ionosphere? Somehow the Moon has done it. Lunar researchers have been struggling with this mystery for years, and they may have finally found a solution.
item.itunes:keywords: NASA, NASA Science, Science, National Aeronautics and Space Administration, ScienceCasts, SMD, Science Mission Directorate, Science@NASA News, Science News, Moon, exosphere, communication, navigation, ionosphere, alien atmospheres, moondust
item.author: michael.brody-1@nasa.gov (NASA Science)

item.title: ScienceCast 35: Stellar Extremophiles
item.itunes:author: NASA Science
item.itunes:subtitle: "GALEX" has found stars forming in extreme galactic environments, places where researchers thought stars should not be. The finding could affect astronomy much as the discovery of microbial extremophiles affected biology in the 1970s.
item.itunes:summary: "GALEX" has found stars forming in extreme galactic environments, places where researchers thought stars should not be. The finding could affect astronomy much as the discovery of microbial extremophiles affected biology in the 1970s.

item.title: ScienceCast 34: A Star with Spiral Arms
item.itunes:author: NASA Science
item.itunes:subtitle: Using a Japanese telescope, NASA-supported researchers have found the first clear case of a star with spiral arms.

item.title: ScienceCast 33: The Sleepy Hollows of Mercury
item.itunes:author: NASA Science
item.itunes:subtitle: NASA's MESSENGER probe has discovered a surprise on Mercury: Something is digging "hollows" in the surface of the innermost planet.

item.title: ScienceCast 32: 600 Mysteries in the Night Sky
item.itunes:author: NASA Science
item.itunes:subtitle: The Fermi Gamma-ray Space Telescope recently produced a map of the night sky. Out of 1873 new sources, nearly 600 were complete mysteries. In this week's ScienceCast, researchers speculate on the nature of the mystery objects.
item.itunes:summary: The Fermi Gamma-ray Space Telescope recently produced a map of the night sky. Out of 1873 new sources, nearly 600 were complete mysteries. In this week's ScienceCast, researchers speculate on the nature of the mystery objects.

item.title: ScienceCast 31: Draconid Meteor Outburst
item.itunes:author: NASA Science
item.itunes:subtitle: Forecasters say Earth is heading for a stream of dust from Comet 21P/Giacobini-Zinner. A close encounter with the comet's fragile debris could spark a meteor outburst over parts of our planet on October 8th.
item.itunes:summary: Forecasters say Earth is heading for a stream of dust from Comet 21P/Giacobini-Zinner. A close encounter with the comet's fragile debris could spark a meteor outburst over parts of our planet on October 8th.

item.title: ScienceCast 30: The Strange Attraction of Gale Crater
item.itunes:author: NASA Science
item.itunes:subtitle: NASA's newest rover Curiosity is getting ready to leave Earth. It's destination: Gale crater on Mars. Today's story from Science@NASA explains the attraction of this Martian crater with a strangely-sculpted mountain the middle.
item.itunes:summary: NASA's newest rover Curiosity is getting ready to leave Earth. It's destination: Gale crater on Mars. Today's story from Science@NASA explains the attraction of this Martian crater with a strangely-sculpted mountain the middle.

item.title: ScienceCast 29: Did Earth Have Two Moons?
item.itunes:author: NASA Science
item.itunes:subtitle: Did our planet once have two moons? Some researchers say so. Moreover, the missing satellite might still be up there--splattered across the far side of the Moon. NASA's GRAIL mission could help confirm or refute the "two moon" hypothesis.
item.itunes:summary: Did our planet once have two moons? Some researchers say so. Moreover, the missing satellite might still be up there--splattered across the far side of the Moon. NASA's GRAIL mission could help confirm or refute the "two moon" hypothesis.

item.title: ScienceCast 27: Cool Stars

item.itunes:author: NASA Science
item.itunes:subtitle: Pluto is a world of mystery waiting to be visited for the 1st time. NASA's New Horizons probe is racing across the solar system for a close encounter that could alter what researchers "know" about Pluto and other small worlds.

item.title: ScienceCast 25: Breath of Fresh Air
item.itunes:author: NASA Science
item.itunes:subtitle: The same kind of oxygen humans breath on Earth has been found in deep space.It's a breath of fresh air for astronomers who have been searching for cosmic "O2" until now without success.

item.title: ScienceCast 24: Bright Perseids Photographed
item.itunes:author: NASA Science
item.itunes:subtitle: On August 13th, space station astronaut Ron Garan photographed a centimeter-sized chunk of comet debris disintegrating in Earth's atmosphere. His rare photo of a meteor from Earth orbit is a must-see.

item.title: ScienceCast 23: Dawn's Smooth Move
item.itunes:author: NASA Science
item.itunes:subtitle: NASA's Dawn spacecraft doesn't do things like other missions. In July it slipped into orbit around asteroid Vesta using a smooth move that made mission planners want to get up and dance.

item.itunes:author: NASA Science
item.itunes:subtitle: If you're camping out and can't sleep, maybe your slumber is being interrupted by the flash of meteors. The summer Perseid meteor shower is getting underway as Earth enters the debris stream from comet Swift-Tuttle.

item.title: ScienceCast 01: NanoSail-D
item.itunes:author: NASA Science
item.itunes:subtitle: High overhead, out of the darkness, a bright light surges into view. For 5 to 10 seconds it outshines the brightest stars in the sky, mimicking a supernova, perhaps even casting faint shadows at your feet.

channel.media:description: NASA Science news is too exciting for plain text. Educational "ScienceCast" videos are fun, lively, entertaining--anything but plain. Join us for a new episode weekly as we look into the science behind discoveries on Earth, the Solar System, and beyond...
